dt.t: We led out more rope and {wi}fixed{/wi} it in place up steeper snow.

dt: {bc}to give a permanent or final form to: such as
{bc}to change into a stable compound or available form
{bc}to kill, harden, and preserve for microscopic study
{bc}to make the image of (a photographic film) permanent by removing unused salts

dt.t: The tables on the ship were {it}fixed{/it} to the floor.
They thought they could cheat me, but I {wi}fixed{/wi} them good.

dt: {bc}to influence the actions, outcome, or effect of by improper or illegal methods

dt.t: had {wi}fixed{/wi} on the first Saturday in June
All eyes {wi}fixed{/wi} on her as she entered the room.

pt: {sc}fasten{/sc} {sc}fix{/sc} {sc}attach{/sc} {sc}affix{/sc} mean to make something stay firmly in place. {sc}fasten{/sc} implies an action such as tying, buttoning, nailing, locking, or otherwise securing.
{sc}fix{/sc} usually implies a driving in, implanting, or embedding.
{sc}attach{/sc} suggests a connecting or uniting by a bond, link, or tie in order to keep things together.
{sc}affix{/sc} implies an imposing of one thing on another by gluing, impressing, or nailing.

et: Middle English {it}fixen,{/it} derivative of {it}fix{/it} "firmly placed," borrowed from Latin {it}fīxus{/it} "firmly established, unchangeable," for earlier {it}fīctus,{/it} past participle of {it}fīgere{/it} "to drive in, insert, fasten," going back to Indo-European {it}*d{sup}h{/sup}eig{sup}w{/sup}-{/it} "pierce," whence also Lithuanian {it}díegu, díegti{/it} "to sprout, break through"
shortdef: to make firm, stable, or stationary
to give a permanent or final form to: such as
to change into a stable compound or available form
